title: In the Drops: Alex Dowsett’s new book, Apidura saddle pack, SQ Lab gloves, Pearl Izumi kit and the Right to Roam
content:
Cyclist
In the Drops: Alex Dowsett’s new book, Apidura saddle pack, SQ Lab gloves, Pearl Izumi kit and the Right to Roam

What a time to be alive. Mark Cavendish is giving it another go, and I for one can’t wait for the inevitable hype train, stressful sprints, optimism and disappointment to follow. Even if he bags that record win, that it will happen the one year the Tour de France won’t finish in Paris feels wrong.

Cavendish wasn’t the only legend in the news this week: editorial assistant Robyn Davidson’s Pro Log round-up summarised the biggest stories in pro cycling at the moment; intern Flo Clifford did a deep dive into what the Jumbo-Visma and Soudal-QuickStep merger would mean for cycling; former Garmin-Chipotle, GreenEdge rider and Girona legend Christian Meier joined this week’s episode of the Cyclist Magazine Podcast to discuss his new life in trail running; I put together a guide on this weekend’s Gravel World Championships; and we looked back at the first ever Il Lombardia and forward at who the favourites are to win this time around.

Elsewhere Robyn interviewed ex-Wales rugby international Alix Popham who is using the bike to raise awareness of the dangers of head trauma in sport, we’ve also got a review of the Cervélo Soloist, a guide to the best tubeless repair tools, and the Col de Peyresourde Classic Climb.

And finally, issue 145 of Cyclist magazine is out now.

Related Posts

Cyclist Magazine Podcast episode 89: Ex-pro Christian Meier is an elite runner now

UCI Gravel World Championships: Who, what, where, when and why?

Il Lombardia 2023: Everything you need to know

Cyclist magazine issue 145: on sale now!

‘Bloody Minded’ by Alex Dowsett

Speaking of almost retired cyclists, former road racer, now time-trial/gravel racer and YouTuber Alex Dowsett has a book out. ‘Bloody Minded’ documents Dowsett’s life story, from being diagnosed with haemophilia as a child to leaving the WorldTour last year.

It features insights into his Hour Record attempts, stories about Lance Armstrong, Mark Cavendish, Bradley Wiggins and others, coming through the British Academy, that Giro d’Italia stage win and more.

And although his journey through Sky, Movistar, Katusha and Israel-Premier Tech is interesting, it’s his experience with haemophilia that makes his story truly inspirational. He’s the only able-bodied elite sportsperson known to have haemophilia A and considering a crash could be fatal, it’s crazy that he’s a cyclist. I’ve not read it yet as I’ve only just got it but I’m really looking forward to ripping through it this weekend.

  • RRP: £20 (hardcover), £14 (e-book)
  • Buy now from Amazon (£15.32)

Apidura Racing 3L Saddle Pack

I love the idea of bikepacking, riding for multiple days, camping and going really long distances in cool places. It’s been incredibly romanticised and it’s got me. However when it comes to actually thinking about it, I just don’t think that kind of solo mission is for me (I’m more than happy if I don’t have to sort anything out). That’s why Apidura’s latest Racing Saddle Pack appeals to me.

At just 3L it’s not big enough to take everything you need for a great multi-day adventure or race, instead it’s primed for single-days/longer-than-a-day-but-zero-sleeps or Audaxing and because it’s made for racing it’s light – Apidura says it weighs less than 210g.

It’s made with a material called Hexalon, which Apidura says is a laminated fabric developed specifically for the London-based brand that’s lightweight and waterproof, and the attachments have a rubberised nylon called Hypalon for extra protection. It has a roll-top closure and fastens with a three-point system for maximum security. It also has a reflective design, which is obviously very handy.

If you do want to sleep, Apidura has 5L and 7L versions. But sleeping’s for the weak, right?

  • RRP: £115 (3L)
  • Buy now from Condor (£115)

SQ Lab gloves

I’ve long moaned about long-fingered cycling gloves, I’ve even featured several pairs in previous editions of In the Drops, I’m constantly stuck for finding suitable ones that I like, ie, gloves that don’t impact the feel of the handlebars and brakes. Most winter cycling gloves are way too thick, meaning your fingers are so far apart and feel slippy and icky and ugh.

I’ve looked at mountain bike gloves several times, but never taken the jump. Now I’m here, with three different pairs(!) of ergonomics experts SQLab’s One gloves and I think I’ve found the ones.

Firstly the One11, pictured above. I’m going to use SQLab’s words to describe them because they’re accurate and are exactly what I’ve been looking for: ‘remarkably thin’, ‘does not wrinkle’, ‘flexible’, ‘super grip’, ‘classy’. It’s like an M&S advert and rightly the German brand finishes it honestly: ‘It is extremely expensive but it lasts forever.’ Yes, €60 for gloves, but for me it’s often this or ride indoors and I don’t want to ride indoors.

The second pair, the One OXes, are slightly thicker, with suede palms, but the outside is still that really nice and flexible material that helps it feel like socks rather than shoes.

The third pair are the One10s and are made for all-weather. The palms are waterproof but still thin and flexible and have a rain cover for the coldest or wet days that keeps a finger out for easy braking. Personally, I’d probably wear the smaller ones until it’s absolutely necessary, but having the security of that extra insulation and protection in desperate times is a good idea.

  • RRP: €59.95 (One11); €49.95 (One OX); €69.95 (One10)
  • Buy the One11 gloves from Amazon (from £48.98)
  • Buy the One OX gloves from Amazon (£43.80)
  • Buy the One10 gloves from Amazon (from £51.72)

Pearl Izumi Attack kit

I know it’s autumn and brands are starting to push their winter kit but it’s meant to be 23°C here in London this weekend, I wear a base layer all year round and arm/leg warmers will be in use until it’s actually cold, so I don’t care – I’m here to talk about Pearl Izumi’s Attack jersey and bib shorts.

There isn’t anything that’s obviously outstanding about the classic-style kit. It doesn’t have super high-tech sections with silly names and there isn’t chunks of mesh chucked everywhere, but the fit and feel of the Attack kit is just sensational. That’s because Pearl Izumi has taken some of the best features of its premium kit and put them in this better-value package.

Both jersey and bib shorts are made from Select Transfer fabric, which is made with 100% recycled polyester, with minimal seams and grips to keep it in the right place. They’re moisture-wicking, are the right amount of stretchy, and the Select Escape 1:1 chamois is nice and breathable.

Plus, as someone who appreciates a solid earth tone, these two colours are great – brighter options are available if that’s your thing.

  • RRP: £81 (jersey); £95.65 (bib shorts)
  • Buy the Attack jersey now from Pearl Izumi (£81)
  • Buy the Attack bib shorts now from Pearl Izumi (£95.65)

What we’re into this week: Right to Roam and playlist #16

I recently spent a week staying near Dunkeld, about an hour and a half north of Edinburgh, just below the Cairngorms, and it was excellent. We got lucky with the weather and managed to enjoy most of our time outdoors. Obviously some cycling had to be done and I’d never had the chance to make the most of Right to Roam laws before, so riding up private roads and through estates made me feel a bit nervous but when you’re greeted with a nod, a ‘hello’ and an ‘enjoy your ride’, rather than ‘get the f*** off my land’, is amazing.

Being able to access the natural landscape that would be off limits south of the border really got me thinking about how ridiculous it is that there’s only a Right to Roam on 8% of England. That’s nuts. Imagine what’s being hidden away. No wonder it’s so easy to stay stuck inside.

Finally, I’ve put together my 16th playlist of new music I’ve been enjoying since my last In the Drops, with highlights from Zach Bryan, Mitski, Bakar, Holly Humberstone, Omar Apollo, Mac DeMarco. I’ve only dipped into Leeds band English Teacher for the first time and they’re well worth a listen to get two spots.

I’ve also added a few bonus Easy Life songs, not because they’ve released anything new but because they’re being sued by EasyJet’s parent company over their name, despite the fact they were well-established long before EasyGroup launched its EasyLife brand. And EasyJet founder has had the audacity to personally attack the band, calling them ‘brand thieves’ and launched a smear campaign against them. I always preferred RyanAir.

  • Listen to In the Drops #16 on Spotify
  • Check out all my In the Drops playlists
